element.name: Molly's Town by Windsockers, Multi-cache (1.5/1.5)

long-description.p: Oldtown is a good example of a ‘chapel village’ which lead to a widespread investment in chapel building following the re-emergence of institutional Catholicism in the late eighteenth century.

The original chapel, which was built in 1827, became the focal point of the village and attracted a range of other services such as the national school, community hall, priest’s house, shop, public house and forge. The term ‘chapel villages’ has been coined for settlements, which evolved in association with the growing social and cultural importance of the Catholic Church in Irish society.

The Parliamentary Gazette of Ireland 1843-44 states that the population of Oldtown in 1841 was 156 and 27 houses were located within the village area of 10 acres. After the Great Famine of 1848 the census of 1851 states the population of the village as recorded as 32 people.

Molly Weston a heroine of the 1798 rebellion was born near Oldtown. She fought alongside her three brothers at Tara. A memorial was erected to her memory at Oldtown during the 1798 Bi-Centennial in 1998.

Another local celebrity and honorary mascot is a donkey rumoured to be in excess of 80 years of age. Nicknamed Pico by an American visitor to the village in October of 2005, his age is as yet unverified.

Oldtown was the first town in the State to benefit from the Rural Electrification Scheme, run by the Electricity Supply Board from 1946 to 1979. The first electricity pole was ceremoniously erected in November, 1946 at Kilsallaghan, and the first switch-on, was in Oldtown itself, in January 1947. The 50thanniversary of the event was commemorated in the village, by the ESB hosting a dinner, to which families living in the area since 1946, were invited.

More recently in the winter of 1981/1982 a large snowstorm cut off the village for 5 days, eventually the Air Corps had to fly in supplies such as food and medicine via helicopter to relieve the village.
At the above location take note of the dates on the plaque call them A.B.C.D.E.F.G.H
At this location take note of the date and call it W.X.Y.Z
please retrieve and replace the cache with extreme care to prevent Muggles from Discovering the cache.

element.additional-waypoints:
FLZE6A - Cache location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___
S2ZE6A - Stage 2
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

ul.li:
2009-09-21T19:00:00Z : Found it by Serapis
Another quick find after the maths bit, a nice village and a great big tree!. TFTC, TNLNSL. Serapis.

2009-07-19T19:00:00Z : Found it by abra123cadabra
With the weather being kind to us for a while we headed up to Oldtown to do this multi. Stage 1 and 2 where easily found but at stage 3 the GPSr indicated GZ+1m at a potential hiding place. Alas, we couldn't find anything here. Then the other half said if he were to hide something, he'd put it at that other much more impressive location and should we have a look there? Went over with the GPSr in hand and low and behold it again went to GZ+1m. Of course the box was there. OUT: GC The Beginning of Exploration, Smurf TB & Desert Storm Patch IN: Dinosaur

2009-07-12T19:00:00Z : Found it by AbbeyAckbar
(#531 @ 16:56) This cache was number five today. We made our way to the first stage without any trouble, but on our way to the second we had to run for cover as the heavens opened up on us. While we hid under a tree we did the maths to solve the final co-ords and then dashed back to the car once the rain had lightened off.
The final location was a nice spot, if a little hard to park at. We drove past the cache site twice wondering were we could park, then Abbey decided 'to hell with it' & drove her car up to the small area to the front of the cache site, trying not to think about how she was going to reverse back down onto the small windy road [xx(]. We had a little stroll around the site and found the cache easily. We loved the place the cache was hidden [^] The cache was big enough to drop a coin in to and we left the TB that was in it, as we have seen it before.
SL. TFTC! (Also, After turning around Abbey was able to get her car back on the road incident free [:D] )

2009-05-15T19:00:00Z : Found it by kazidrat
Nice multi and lovely final location... In: TB, CWG.. TFTC...[:D]

2008-11-01T19:00:00Z : Found it by theswerve
Found with no problem..nice scenic multi..lovely small village

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Molly's Town
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Oldtown is a good example of a ‘chapel village’ which lead to a widespread investment in chapel building following the re-emergence of institutional Catholicism in the late eighteenth century.

The original chapel, which was built in 1827, became the focal point of the village and attracted a range of other services such as the national school, community hall, priest’s house, shop, public house and forge. The term ‘chapel villages’ has been coined for settlements, which evolved in association with the growing social and cultural importance of the Catholic Church in Irish society.

The Parliamentary Gazette of Ireland 1843-44 states that the population of Oldtown in 1841 was 156 and 27 houses were located within the village area of 10 acres. After the Great Famine of 1848 the census of 1851 states the population of the village as recorded as 32 people.

Molly Weston a heroine of the 1798 rebellion was born near Oldtown. She fought alongside her three brothers at Tara. A memorial was erected to her memory at Oldtown during the 1798 Bi-Centennial in 1998.

Another local celebrity and honorary mascot is a donkey rumoured to be in excess of 80 years of age. Nicknamed Pico by an American visitor to the village in October of 2005, his age is as yet unverified.

Oldtown was the first town in the State to benefit from the Rural Electrification Scheme, run by the Electricity Supply Board from 1946 to 1979. The first electricity pole was ceremoniously erected in November, 1946 at Kilsallaghan, and the first switch-on, was in Oldtown itself, in January 1947. The 50thanniversary of the event was commemorated in the village, by the ESB hosting a dinner, to which families living in the area since 1946, were invited.

More recently in the winter of 1981/1982 a large snowstorm cut off the village for 5 days, eventually the Air Corps had to fly in supplies such as food and medicine via helicopter to relieve the village.

The Cache

Stage one

At the above location take note of the dates on the plaque call them A.B.C.D.E.F.G.H

Stage Two

Go to N53 (G+H)A.(D-G)(B-A)D W6 AF.(D*G)0

At this location take note of the date and call it W.X.Y.Z

Final Location

N53 (A+C+H)W.X(X-W)(Z-G) W6 AY.(Z/G)G(B-Y)

please retrieve and replace the cache with extreme care to prevent Muggles from Discovering the cache.


The Windsockers

Additional Waypoints

FLZE6A - Cache location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

S2ZE6A - Stage 2
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___
